fig, axes = plt.subplots(3, 3, figsize=(20, 12))
sns.boxplot(x='Total Cases',data=df,ax=axes[0,0])
sns.boxplot(x='Total Deaths',data=df,ax=axes[0,1])
sns.boxplot(x='Total Recovered',data=df,ax=axes[0,2])
sns.boxplot(x='Active Cases',data=df,ax=axes[1,0])
sns.boxplot(x='Total Cases/1 mil population',data=df,ax=axes[1,1])
sns.boxplot(x='Death/1 mil population',data=df,ax=axes[1,2])
sns.boxplot(x='Total Tests',data=df,ax=axes[2,0])
sns.boxplot(x='Tests/1 mil population',data=df,ax=axes[2,1])
sns.boxplot(x='Population',data=df,ax=axes[2,2])
source.bc51d044: plot_model(kmeans, plot = 'distribution', feature = 'Total Cases/1 mil population')
source.c89e131b:
![image.png](attachment:d9fb8082-95c1-4371-ac8f-bc8da6515580.png)

* Test/1M pop in Africa is only 0.8% of World Average. Tot Cases/1M pop in Africa is 50%, and Deaths/1M pop in Africa is 40% of World Average.
* Tot Cases/1M pop to Test/1M pop in Africa is 13.7%, which is much higher than that of World Average.
* Max of Test/1M pop in Africa is 734,241 is still absolutely lower than World Average 14,495,409.
source.eae19bde:
# Objective
# I tiried to find the defference between countries in Africa and World Average in data for Cases, Deaths and Test, although only 15 Africa countries meet 10% target share of total population who received a full dose schedule.


# You can also find "Vaccine Gap Analysis" https://www.kaggle.com/sasakitetsuya/vaccine-gap-in-the-world

* Test/1M pop of above 7 countries are under World Average.

**How we can deliver not only Vaccines but also Testing tool are very important.**
